conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the graph in Figure 2 to determine the relationship between force and acceleration, then calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction and the mass of object A.
Figure 1 shows objects A and B stacked on a smooth surface with a force F applied to A. Figure 2 shows a graph of acceleration a versus force F, with a slope of 1/10 m·s⁻²·N⁻¹.
The graph indicates a linear relationship between acceleration a and force F, with a slope of 1/10.
When F = 0, the acceleration a = 0, aligning with expected behavior under zero force.
With applied force F, the acceleration a of object A is a = F/10.
The force F can be expressed as F = m · g where m is the mass of object A and g is gravitational acceleration (g = 10 m·s⁻²).
Substituting, a = m · g/10 = m · 10/10 = m.
From the graph, when F = 10 N, the acceleration a = 1 m·s⁻².
This implies that the mass of object A is m = 1 kg.
The horizontal force F_kinetic required to move both objects A and B is F_kinetic = μ · m · g, where μ is the coefficient of kinetic friction.
Given F_kinetic = 6 N and m = 1 kg, we find μ = F_kinetic/(m · g) = 6/(1 · 10) = 0.6.
The mass of object A is 1 kg and the coefficient of kinetic friction between objects A and B is 0.6.
